title: Alerting: Increase size of kvstore value type for MySQL to LONGTEXT

labels.name: no-backport
labels.description: Skip backport of PR

labels.name: area/alerting/migration
labels.description: Issues relating to legacy alerting migration

commits_data.message:
Alerting: Increase size of kvstore value type for MySQL to LONGTEXT

alertmanager uses the kvstore to persist its notification log and the current
column limit for MySQL (16.7mb) puts the maximum entries at a level that is
potentially achievable for heavy alerting users (~40-80k entries).

In comparison, the current type for PSQL (TEXT) is effectively unlimited and
I believe SQLIte defaults to 2gb which is also plenty of leeway.

comments_data.body: I wonder if we want to mention MYSQL in migration name
Oh boy, I already felt bad with how long it currently is :sweat_smile: but yes I'll add it.

commits_data.message: Raise batch size, now that we pay attention to it
Separate cancellable batch implementation to allow for multi-statement callbacks, add overload for single-statement use
Use split-out utility in outer batching loop so it respects context cancellation
Work around parameter limit on sqlite for large batches
Bulk insert test data in DB
Refactor test to customise test data creation
Add test for catching SQLITE_MAX_VARIABLE_NUMBER limit
Turn annotation cleanup test to integration tests

comments_data.body:
This is done purely for ephemeral instance purposes, so we can observe the cleanup happening more often in manual testing.

@alexweav: revert this line before submission.

Since the new cleanup uses multiple SQL statements, the old `executeUntilDoneOrCancelled` which did the batch looping needed to be split in half. The batching and looping is now separated from the database interaction, takes a generic callback instead.

That way, we can reuse the context cancellation logic, even though the SQL pattern is now different.
nit; better add an else condition and fail if for any reason, it's empty to prevent from querying the whole table
maybe we could consider splitting this query as well? I suspect that it could cause similar deadlock issues?
nit; I would suggest using placeholders and pass the `ids` as arguments to the `session.Exec()` below to prevent parsing it each time it is executed
kind reminder!
Good idea, since the batch size is constant it'll be the same number of parameters each time except for the last one, so it can really re-use the parsed query a lot :+1:
Done :+1:

I think that comparing with the length of the IDs is more obvious
```suggestion
	if r.db.GetDBType() == migrator.SQLite && len(ids) > sqliteParameterLimit {
```

SQLITE_MAX_VARIABLE_NUMBER defaults to 999 for SQLite versions prior to 3.32.0 (2020-05-22) or 32766 for SQLite versions after 3.32.0
however it can be set to something lower [at run-time](https://www.sqlite.org/c3ref/limit.html)

I have noticed also that postgres has [a similar limit](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/current/limits.html) but it's higher (65,535)

so I wonder if it's better to fallback on this case only if the other query fails first

comments_data.body: maybe the min value should be the current default min? this might avoid the scrolling issues

I think we were thinking of just having the width / height options without the auto / manual toggle (with the defaults of the width / height being what they currently are)

Is that correct @leeoniya?

I remember that we decided to have this option and @adela-almasan noted that in the ticket description. Also, it's a good idea to have something like a "reset" option to set the tooltip size to default values.

Good point! But what if the user wants to make it a bit smaller than default? 😁
But sure we can do this, looks like a good protection against layout breaking.

i personally like that the old tooltips are nice and compact. it allows them not to hide the viz unnecessarily.

i would remove any kind of width or min width, and use an implicit maxWidth of what we currently have for width. and allow users to set maxWidth expicitly

yeah we dont want a toggle. we just want options for maxWidth and maxHeight.

if those are not supplied by user then we will use whatever internal defaults we choose (auto)
What's the data-viz convention for using `enum`s here vs `const`s? I've seen both in the code base, but would love to understand if our squad has a de facto convention.
I see a significant amount of `TODO`s in some of the files we own. Are we planning on addressing this tech debt in the future?
Will `maxWidth` and `maxHeight` ever be "undefined", since we give a default value above?
Good catch, thanks!
As far as I see, those are mostly related to documentation, they probably already added but this file left not updated 🤷🏻‍♂️

Not sure that I understand the question. `const` is something to avoid reassigning and `enum` is a type. I don't see any `versus` situation here, you even can use `const enum` if needed 😁
I'd like to use `const` when it's just a simple type variable like `number`, `string`, etc. and `enum` for a set of constants.

There is no specific convention in the team, just keep in mind that your code gonna read someone else, so keep it clean and readable/maintainable as possible 😁

can we rename these to `maxHeight` and `maxWidth`?

we're already inside tooltip options, so no need to repeat "tooltip"
`tooltip.maxWidth`
`tooltip.maxHeight`

let's change this to be a `maxWidth` property. i know this will make the tooltip width adjust to content (like the old one), but it makes the tooltip compact instead of taking up a minimum amount of space even when the content is small.
let's use `??` here instead of `||`
maxWidth/maxHeight

this is kind of weird. except for zoom options, the other props are all tooltip options as well.

maybe we can just pass `maxWidth` and `maxHeight` as separate props?

in the future we may rename this plugin to `CursorInteractionPlugin` and then we may want to nest a bit more clearly. like `{tooltip: {maxWidth, maxHeight, hoverMode, render}, zoom: {query, client}}`.

but for now (with the current naming), let's keep it flat.

What I mean was, in my experience in the grafana code base, enums are often used when defining a collection of related constants - which these two values seem to be. I've seen other developers go the enum path when choosing to define related values in this way, so I was just curious if we had a convention. 😁👍

Hm, good point! I don't have a strong opinion about it, I'm trying to use common sense to organize constants... We can make some guideline 😁 cc @nmarrs 
Looks like in this particular case we can use enum.

So if the user enters a value of '0' for a max width, does that mean the tool tip still renders just has no width, and therefore is invisible? At least if we use ||, than a zero value will at least render the default value.

I really don't have any strong feelings either way, I just want to make sure I'm adhering to the principle of making all of our visualizations as similar as possible. I know standardization is part of the plan moving forward, so I think having a solid understanding as a team of what we want our conventions to be would be helpful. :-)

first rule of dataviz, there are no rules.

consts tend to be faster than enums (unless they're `const enum`s :)

slider input probably won't allow an empty default that is true "auto", right?

i think a number input here that is blank by default might be better.
oh, yes, it can be zero, good catch 👍🏻

yeah, it's not
slider is numeric and if we remove `defaultValue` at all it will set it to zero
just checked, if we remove `defaultValue` it will ignore this property at all and we gonna set default value inside TooltipPlugin2
so, blank by default also works 🙂

commits_data.message: Scenes/PanelEdit: Replace panel when commiting editor changes
Clone panel rather than setting it as body directly

comments_data.body:
This is problematic as the `parent` for the panel manager's `state.panel` is already set. This this will result in a warning in the console.

I wonder why the state clone does not work?

> I wonder why the state clone does not work?

I think because VizPanel's _plugin property isn't actually part of the state

Ah, you may be right!  But I think what we can do is actually is clone the managed panel when navigating back:

```
sourcePanel.parent.setState({ body: panelMngr.state.panel.clone() });
```

I think this should solve the problem, but may have memory implications...
Otherwise we would have to implement the state change handler in the `VizPanel` directly in order to support VizPanel plugin type change :(
Right, I think that was something that was mentioned as something to avoid in the initial panel edit PR
Anyway, will add the clone change and see what happens

title: Supplementary queries: allow plugin decoupling by allowing providers to return a request instance

labels.name: no-backport
labels.description: Skip backport of PR

labels.name: no-changelog
labels.description: Skip including change in changelog/release notes

commits_data.message: Supplementary queries: add support for providers returning a request instance

getLogLevelFromKey: fix key type

Why number??

Revert "getLogLevelFromKey: fix key type"

This reverts commit 14a95298a6f803cc3270e0421b2e04dd0d65f131.

Datasources: remove unnecessary check

The switch is doing the same job
datasource_srv: sync mock with real api
Supplementary queries: pass targets from getSupplementaryQueryProvider
LogsVolumeQueryOptions: remove range and make extract level optional
logsModel: add missing range to test data
DataSourceWithSupplementaryQueriesSupport: update interface with deprecated and new methods
Supplementary queries: add support for the new method
Supplementary queries: add test for the legacy API
Merge branch 'matyax/decouple-logs-volume' of github.com:grafana/grafana into matyax/decouple-logs-volume

comments_data.body: As mentioned in my previous PR, we are not recommending logsVolume/logsSample for external plugin developers and currently there is no (not super hard) way to use logs volume. Also based on our research, no internally made logs plugin is using logs volume api. Therefore I would keep this API as `: DataQueryRequest<TQuery> | undefined;`
Based on my comment above, this should be just if `(!provider)`
I think we want to keep this required and then make `extractLevel` optional.
Makes sense! Done
Yes, range and targets are required for re-using results on zoom-in: https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/aa670280fc46b2d96e3096f1395e5145c715cb44/public/app/features/explore/state/query.ts#L878

This logic may not be applicable to all data sources. I wonder if we may need to be more flexible to allow overriding it as well. At least we should support data plane spec (which I think should read level from `severity`), this way data sources could ensure the level is extracted correctly with proper data frame format.
Maybe log volume response should also be part of data plane? 🤔

It's applicable to the 2 data sources that currently support logs volume (Loki and Elasticsearch), and can also be overriden by `options`: https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/80281/files#diff-cda90ed4a0399053b7808392e0fb6b8f03ed64289acecb0978dc0ba544dd40f8R637
@ifrost I really don't see where `range` and `targets` are used for zoom-in, could you please point me to where are they used?

There's no need to add that, when in both cases the switch is already doing that work:

https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/plugins/datasource/elasticsearch/datasource.ts#L626

https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/plugins/datasource/loki/datasource.ts#L249

I also found a bit awkward that the function that knows about and provides supplementary queries, `getSupportedSupplementaryQueryTypes`, has to ask itself about the supported supplementary queries.

`datasource.getSupportedSupplementaryQueryTypes()` used externally makes a lot of sense, but internally in that context seems very redundant.

Hm... but to override `options` the plugin would need to call `queryLogsVolume` from `logsModel` which wouldn't have access to, right? So there won't be an easy way to override options in plugins code 🤔

Thank you @ifrost ! I'm just learning that we had that in place for logs volume.

To further ellaborate on the reason why I made this change, in the two places where we call `queryLogsVolume()` and use `options`, `options.range` is `===` `request.range`. So if the value is exactly the same and can be grabbed from the `logsVolumeRequest: DataQueryRequest<TQuery>,` argument, I don't see the point of using `options.range`. Same for `options.targets`.

https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/plugins/datasource/loki/datasource.ts#L273-L274

https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/plugins/datasource/elasticsearch/datasource.ts#L645-L646

Again, in both places `options.range` and `options.targets` are exactly the same as those in `request: DataQueryRequest`.

There might be something else that I'm not seeing, as I'm becoming more familiar with this implementation, so I will take a second look with more context. In the mean time, if you can spot something that I'm missing, please let me know.
I finally figured out why it was not working. Will update tomorrow.
I think the key here is _may not_. So far we have 2 implementations using logs volume, and both share the same level extraction logic. For now I would say YAGNI. What do you think?

It took me so long to figure out why it was not working, because this not null assertion operator (!) was hiding a potential bug: https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/public/app/features/explore/utils/supplementaryQueries.ts#L82

>  I don't see the point of using options.range. Same for options.targets.

`options.targets` was needed to pass the targets from the original requests not targets of the log volume requests. 

`options.range` was needed in the past when a partial log volume was rendered and the returned range didn't match the request range. But we moved the implementation of partial log volume out of data sources so maybe we don't need it anymore 🤔

I'm just concerned about backwards compatibility, and a dreadful maintenance of multiple returned results if we add one more on top of it when we need it... Do you need getProvider() API to be public or we will keep it internal? I'm also now wondering if we need to support handling Observable returned from `getProvider` as it seems Elastic and Loki will always return a request now 🤔  In theory we could rename `getProvider` to `mapToSupplementaryRequest` 🤔

> In theory we could rename getProvider to mapToSupplementaryRequest 🤔

+1 absolutely.

> options.targets was needed to pass the targets from the original requests not targets of the log volume requests.

Yeah! I eventually saw this, and updated the implementation to allow reuse of supplementary queries.

> But we moved the implementation of partial log volume out of data sources so maybe we don't need it anymore 🤔

It seems that we don't. `targets` was being modified inside `getDataProvider`, but range was always === to the original one.

I think this logic will actually be applicable for all data sources, that return correct data frames in  `Time Series Wide Format` or `Time Series Multi Format` with `level` label. Maybe instead of `extractLevel` function we just need the way to override `level` label, if it does not have name `level`. That way data sources can override getting of level, and we support it correctly for every data source that produces valid data plane compatible frames. 

And considering log volume hasn't worked for any data source besides Loki and Elasticsearch, we don't need to worry about backward compatibility.

> I'm also now wondering if we need to support handling Observable returned from getProvider as it seems Elastic and Loki will always return a request now 🤔

I think this was actually removed and we only expect `DataQueryRequest<TQuery>` and not observable.

```
getDataProvider(
    type: SupplementaryQueryType,
    request: DataQueryRequest<TQuery>
  ): DataQueryRequest<TQuery> | undefined;
  ```

> In theory we could rename getProvider to mapToSupplementaryRequest

I can of agree that we could rename `getProvider`.  I would name it `getSupplementaryQueryRequest`
`getSupplementaryQueryRequest` sounds great.

Just to confirm, what is the decision related to logs volume query options and level overrided:
- we don't need it for now
- we want to have it as function
- instead of function, we want to just have the option to specify the name of `level` field (e.g. somewhere it can be `error_level`, or `LVL`, or `LEVEL`  or anything else?
Both `we don't need it for now` and `option to specify the level field` works for me. Now that we're at it, we can easily add support to specify the `level` field and win-win.

Apart from Loki and Elasticsearch there's one more internal implementation in [ClickHouse Datasource](https://github.com/grafana/clickhouse-datasource/blob/main/src/data/CHDatasource.ts#L63). 

We need to keep the old method, though it can be marked as deprecated. We can introduce a new called `getSupplementaryQueryRequest`. ClickHouse should be updated and only then the old method can be removed, but a big question is how many versions back we need to support 🤔  What are the latest guidelines for internal plugins? Do you own the ClickHouse plugin as well? Would it be possible to use the new `getSupplementaryQueryRequest` and the current level extraction logic in that plugin? 🤔

Maybe we could send a PR to update ClickHouse with these changes? I think doing in two steps would be the longer path just for one data source. I wouldn't mind at all doing that as a follow up to the API changes here. What do you all think? Nice catch btw, we almost miss it!

It depends on when new version of a plugin is released and how many previous versions of Grafana we need to support. If we release the change in the API before plugin is updated it will stop working. Also, I think plugins are not updated automatically, so I guess there's need to be some grace period with backwards compatibility anyway. What guidelines do you have for newly externalized plugins?
I don't understand this first part of the comment.

title: Geomap: Support geojson styling properties

labels.name: type/docs
labels.description: Flags the technical writing team for documentation support; auto adds to org-wide docs project

labels.name: no-backport
labels.description: Skip backport of PR

commits_data.message: Move styleStrings outside of style function
Add styling note to geoJSON docs
Add support for all geojson types and update example

comments_data.body: move this outside the inner loop -- currently it will be created for each feature
is this worth adding to the distribution?  800k for this kinda essoteric example seems not worth it.  Perhaps a smaller test example?  that exercises points, lines, and polygons?
Good catch!
Adding a simpler example dedicated as a style example.
I think we're no longer using Hugo `admonition` short codes in favor of `> **Note:** <you're note here>` syntax. @imatwawana can you confirm?
We favour `admonition` shortcodes, but in the `transformations.md` file we can't use them because of how it's generated, so that might be what's causing confusion here.
Thanks @imatwawana . Sorry for the misunderstanding! :)

```suggestion
Styles can be set within the `properties` object of the GeoJSON with support for the following geometries:
```

Do we need both the quotation marks and the bold? If these are properties in the JSON object, I would suggest the following formatting: 
```suggestion
  - `fill` - The color of the interior of the polygon
  - `fill-opacity` - The opacity of the interior of the polygon
  - `stroke-width` - The width of the line component of the polygon
```
Good suggestions, but will keep double quotes which matches the format of the json standard.
Adding the hyphen and capitalization, but keeping the double quotes to be consistent with the geojson standard.

I'm a bit concerned about the property comparisons here. Seems like there could be a situation in which we have M `featureProps` along with N style strings resulting in worse case M*N in terms of comparisons. Probably not meaningful in small layers, but I could see this being hairy in larger ones potentially.

Thanks for testing it!

Perhaps we could do the embedded styling check for geojson on first load and store a file content hash with hasStyling boolean inside of the panel json. That way, if there is no embedded styling in a particular source (that contents hasn't changed), it avoids these loops altogether. Of course doing the hash check wouldn't be free and there may be a crossover point where it doesn't make sense. For the case where embedded styling is found, we could store a comprehensive map of which styles were used to reduce these loops.

TLDR: we should follow-up on how to [better optimize this](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/issues/80637).
Nit: most other places in our codebase I think we capitalize `enum` properties.

Good point. I wanted it to match the [StyleConfigValues properties](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/18b9c8fd5fda882013e5224e48ce029d8259aee7/public/app/plugins/panel/geomap/style/types.ts#L116), but I suppose there may be a cleaner way to approach this.
That sounds like a really good way forward! Really appreciate the thoughtful approach here 😄

comments_data.body:
```suggestion
  const [params] = useQueryParams();
```

Just to be consistent with the other places we use this
Does this mean we are not too worried about window resizing? If we want to consider window resizing we can put this in a media query instead?

I think we can merge this logic, something like 

```
const [showReturnToPrevious, setShowReturnToPrevious] = React.useState(params?.__returnToTitle && params?.__returnToUrl && location.pathname !== params.__returnToUrl);
```

and then later in the useEffect also just set this directly. we could create a small helper

```
const shouldShow = (params) => params?.__returnToTitle && params?.__returnToUrl && location.pathname !== params.__returnToUrl
```

and use it in both. Wdyt?

This creates a strange pattern to me, when I press the 'x' and then press the browser back button it keeps the same URL, one more back and it readds the params to the URL. I think we need to investigate this and maybe use `locationService.replace`, but I would double check what is the intended UX here.
If we already have text overflow ellipsis do we need this calculation still?
Why do we pass title twice as `children` and as `title` prop?
I know this is draft but just a reminder to translate this and the aria-label 😄
can this live in `AppChrome` instead? 🤔 then you wouldn't really need `ReturnToPreviousWrapper` at all
why do we need optional chaining and `toString`? the types say it's always there, and it's always a string
i don't think this is used

think we could make these optional, then later on line 56 you can just say
```tsx
returnToPrevious: getReturnToPrevious()
```
Good catch! It should be needed once and then I forgot it was there 😓
Do you still need this for something?

title: Auth: reload SSO settings for HA setups

labels.name: no-changelog
labels.description: Skip including change in changelog/release notes

commits_data.message: reload SSO settings for HA setups
fetch all sso settings with one sql query

comments_data.body: We probably always need to schedule the reload functionality. This is a flag to get _live_ working correctly in a HA setup but there is nothing stopping someone from running HA without this flag set. Also _live_ can be disabled
Thanks for confirming, I wasn't sure about that flag either.
This will do a _sql_ query for each _reloadable_, can we batch this? Alternative fetch everything stored in the db upfront and then trigger reload for each provider?

Yes, this does an sql query for each provider. One optimization would be to use the list method to get all settings for all providers in one sql query, but at the moment the list method is redacting the secrets. I'll try to make it work.

Sorry did not think of this earlier but we should probably register this as a background service. Then this would gracefully terminate if grafana stops.

What you need to do is register this service [here](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/pkg/registry/backgroundsvcs/background_services.go).

You can look at https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/pkg/services/anonymous/anonimpl/impl.go#L172 for how this is usually implemented

I refactored this function to call the list method in order to get all sso settings with one sql query for all providers.

@colin-stuart since you are working on the list endpoint, can you please make sure that the list API endpoint is calling a separate service method that returns the sso settings with secrets redacted? Similar to what you did for the GET endpoint (`GetForProvider` and `GetForProviderWithRedactedSecrets`).
Done.
Should we make this time configurable?
Configurable from the ini file or just make it a constant? I'm wondering if we can put this in the ini file and let the users opt out from running this background reload process.
Yes putting this in ini file. Great point that it would be possible to opt out from there

title: Explore: Fix incorrect interpolation of table title

labels.name: no-backport
labels.description: Skip backport of PR

labels.name: no-changelog
labels.description: Skip including change in changelog/release notes

commits_data.message: Explore: Fix incorrect interpolation of table title
Revert removal of title attr in headerContent
Add basic tests for Trans component

comments_data.body:
React prevents XSS attacks out of the box ([link](https://legacy.reactjs.org/docs/introducing-jsx.html#jsx-prevents-injection-attacks)), but we can't be sure that internationalized strings will always be used within React, so settings using `escapeValue: false` in `options` on line 31 doesn't seem safe enough.

Overriding `shouldUnescape` in `<Trans />` means we can be sure it will only be rendered in React components.

Both here and on line 249, `title` is used in `PanelMenu` to generate a more descriptive `aria-label`. Using a `ReactElement` instead of a string means we can't use it in `aria-label`, which means it will be generic `Menu for panel with no title` 🤔

An alternative solution would overriding `escapeValue` in this specific case, like so:

```suggestion
    return name ?
      t('explore.table.title-with-name', 'Table - {{name}}', { name, interpolation: { escapeValue: false } }) :
      t('explore.table.title', 'Table');
```
If your intentions is to always set `shouldUnescape` to true you should place if after the `{...props}` spread statement. Otherwise it can be overridden in the passed props.
The intention is that it can be overridden in the passed props.

Can we add some unit tests to catch potential changes in i18next here? It should also assert your desired behaviour (that prometheus selectors render correctly)

It doesn't need to be super thorough, but just assert that things like HTML is still being escaped by either react or i18next :)

Good idea! I added 2 test cases (rendering `<script></script` with and without `shouldUnescape={false}`). Correct Prometheus selectors rendering is asserted in `public/app/features/explore/Table/TableContainer.test.tsx`

comments_data.body:
Is this correct? should not be the opposite?
` key={filterState.dashboardUid ?  'dashboard-defined' : 'dashboard-not-defined'}`
why are we removing this ` setFilterKey((key) => key + 1);` ??
Yes, it should 😅
he biggest issue is here, we should only show this button if the dashboard has panels with associated alert rules
Not needed for the state change filter

This situation is a bit tricky because we need to wait for an API response before making a decision. So, I added the entire logic to the `AlertRulesToolbarButton` component, which renders `null` instead of a `button` when there are no rules.
I don't think we want to do this on every page, slows down the initial load & startup for everything
any way to do this lazy (on demand when needed)

How else can we use the `addCustomRightAction` function from Alerting? 
`initAlerting` doesn't wait for rules to be loaded. It only adds the toolbar button

I think this is fine actually. Was thinking initially we could have that action added directly in the component rendering the toolbar, but this seems more reasonable as it decouples alerting from dashboarding. 

I only suggest to rename this function to be `initAlertingToolbarActions`.

The `initAlerting` function only initializes the `addCustomRightAction`. Then the button lazily calls the Alerting API to figure out whether it should render. 
The `initAlerting` call shouldn't impact the initial load in any way
@dprokop how is this fine? does not work around all the webpack chunking making so we have to load every alerting asset on every page load (before the app is booted) , not matter the route?

if we use React.lazy here for the AlertRulesToolbarButton we would not include all of alerting into the app webpack chunk. 

@dprokop or am I missing something?
I didn't think about it. You may be right that we need to React.lazy this component
I added React.lazy here to delay the toolbar button loading and also I lazily load the Alert rules drawer so the toolbar button footprint is really small

comments_data.body:
🤔 I see you are handling the local variable query state with the react `query` (line 13), I think we can use here that, right?

`variable.setState({ query: query });`
The same here, we can use the `allValue` prop from react :)
Solved :)
Solved! Good catch! 💯
what is the purpose of these states?
Can't this use variable.state.loading?
why is this not just `<CustomVariableEditor variable={this.props.variable} />`

```suggestion
      <SelectionOptionsForm variable={variable} />
```
ah, is component shared between old and new architecture?
ah think I see how they are used. But you can just use defaultValue={...} and then only use the blur callbacks, no need for these useState
Yes, this is shared, this is the point where we break between old and new to make it agnostic to data structure
Same reason what I mentioned here https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/80193#discussion_r1455328976

Do not change the variable state for every `onChange`, to avoid dependencies resolving or other state changes. When onblur, we commit these changes, but in the meantime, we don't need to update the variable scene state if the value is not definitive.
This is a good one! Let me try! 👀
@ivanortegaalba yes, but you can do that without a React.useState, use defaultValue instead (on the inputs )
Why does all value need blur and onChange? I think it can just have onChange (and it handles the onBlur internally)

I tried, and I found the `loading` state is always false, because in the [`MultiValueVariable`](https://github.com/grafana/scenes/blob/main/packages/scenes/src/variables/variants/MultiValueVariable.ts#L76), running `validateAndUpdate` it never sets the loading to `true` when calling `updateValueGivenNewOptions`. 

I'm working with QueryVariableEditor where the data is async for real, so I'll move everything to use the variable loading state. If we do that now, the component doesn't re-render because the state doesn't change.

yep, you're completely right, I did it in this way to not refactor all the old part 😓 any variable input field implements `defaultValue` but all of them are used in every form for every variable type in the old forms.

I think it is a good refactor to do tbh, but I'd leave it out of this PR scope, since there are 2 more PR relaying on these.

But why would you need to refactor the old part? If we added `defaultValue` as an optional property to the VariableTextField, VariableTextAreaField then you get rid of it straight away. The onChange/onBlur props are optional already, so should be a minimal change.
shall we eliminate these selectors and just add the `data-testid` in the `selectionOptionsMultiSwitch`?
Done! I forgot about that one!
Sorry, it was not the old part, it is the different layers on top of those components. I pushed a new commit with all the changes, now it uses the `defaultValue` 😄

comments_data.body: this `Body` is no longer closed?

The logger before was populated with the `context` information. `backend.Logger` is just the default logger. So I think you need to:

- Instantiate the logger as done with testdata: https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/pkg/tsdb/grafana-testdata-datasource/testdata.go#L34 
- Then, in each method, use `s.logger.FromContext` to get a custom logger with contextual info (as it was done before).

After that, if you compare log entries, they should be similar before and after the change.

Can you use the SDK http provider for this as Azure does? https://github.com/grafana/grafana/blob/main/pkg/tsdb/azuremonitor/azuremonitor.go/#L28
If not, we should move this interface definition to the SDK rather than copying it here.
this change seems unrelated? `sloQ` -> `nil`
10.3.0-pre needs to be replaced with 10.4.0-pre
Instead of removing this I think we should use the tracer from the SDK? I think that's applicable? cc @andresmgot

I think that the tracer is still used: [link](https://github.com/grafana/grafana/pull/80181/files#diff-e0d8854117661da605b3d4b545db968683557373389b57e2a8143ce13ef487e3R128). We probably don't need to store it in the service (I'm no tracer expert :D)
That's correct, `backend.DefaultTracer()` is the tracer provided by the SDK and the dependency from the tracer in `pkg/infra/tracing` can be removed
This is still not fully solved, you need to replace all `backend.Logger` appearances and `QueryData` was using `.FromContext` before so we should probably keep it.
Thanks @andresmgot. I replaced `backend.Logger` and added back in the context as well as updated the corresponding tests.
